articles.headline: To Help Democrats in the Fall, Obama May Stay Away
articles.snippet: President Obama is stepping up his involvement in the fight to preserve the Democratic Party’s control of Congress, but he may avoid appearances in some competitive districts.
articles.abstract: President Obama is stepping up his involvement in the fight to preserve the Democratic Party’s control of Congress, but he may avoid appearances in some competitive districts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As lunch was served in the Roosevelt Room of the White House one day last week, President Obama assured the nine Democratic members of Congress sitting around the table that he would do anything he could to help them survive their fall elections.

articles.headline: Targeted Killing Is New U.S. Focus in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is starting to count more heavily on hunting down insurgents and less on winning over civilians.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is starting to count more heavily on hunting down insurgents and less on winning over civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When President Obama announced his new war plan for Afghanistan last year, the centerpiece of the strategy  and a big part of the rationale for sending 30,000 additional troops  was to safeguard the Afghan people, provide them with a competent government and win their allegiance.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Emirates to Cut Data Services of BlackBerry
articles.snippet: The United Arab Emirates said that it cannot adequately monitor the company’s e-mail and text messaging services.
articles.abstract: The United Arab Emirates said that it cannot adequately monitor the company’s e-mail and text messaging services.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United Arab Emirates, citing security concerns, said Sunday that it would suspend BlackBerry mobile services like e-mail and text messaging beginning in October, the latest high-stakes clash between governments and communications providers over the flow of digital information.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Robert F. Worth

articles.headline: Bing and Google in a Race for Features
articles.snippet: While Google is dominant in search, it has been watching Bing and in some cases mimicking some innovations.
articles.abstract: While Google is dominant in search, it has been watching Bing and in some cases mimicking some innovations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Edwin Perello discovered that Bing, the Microsoft search engine, could find addresses in his rural Indiana town when Google could not. Laura Michelson, an administrative assistant in San Francisco, was lured by Bing’s flight fare tracker. Paul Callan, a photography buff in Chicago, fell for Bing’s vivid background images.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Ashlee Vance

articles.headline: Media Companies Try Getting Social With Tumblr
articles.snippet: Following Facebook and Twitter’s success, Tumblr, a fast-growing blogging service based in New York, has attracted interest from major news publishers.
articles.abstract: Following Facebook and Twitter’s success, Tumblr, a fast-growing blogging service based in New York, has attracted interest from major news publishers.
articles.lead_paragraph: By now, plenty of traditional media companies have hopped on the social media bandwagon, pumping out news updates on Facebook and Twitter.

articles.headline: State-Owned Bidders Fuel China’s Land Boom
articles.snippet: Even as China tries to avoid a debt-driven real estate bubble, state-owned companies have been driving up prices by outbidding private developers for land.
articles.abstract: Even as China tries to avoid a debt-driven real estate bubble, state-owned companies have been driving up prices by outbidding private developers for land.
articles.lead_paragraph: WUHU, China  The Anhui Salt Industry Corporation is a state-owned company that has 11,000 employees, access to government salt mines and a Communist Party boss.

articles.headline: Editor’s Impact Begins With a Capital O
articles.snippet: Susan Casey’s résumé includes chasing great white sharks, but her latest challenge is remaking O magazine.
articles.abstract: Susan Casey’s résumé includes chasing great white sharks, but her latest challenge is remaking O magazine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Susan Casey’s publishing résumé reflects what one would expect from someone who has chased great white sharks in California, stalked elk in Colorado and tramped the oil-slicked marshlands of Louisiana. Editor of Sports Illustrated Women? Check. Creative director of Outside? Check. Author of a book on sharks and another on extreme surfing? Check, check.

articles.headline: Couric’s Future Clouded by CNN
articles.snippet: An unexpected slide in Larry King’s ratings compressed the schedule for finding his successor.
articles.abstract: An unexpected slide in Larry King’s ratings compressed the schedule for finding his successor.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, whenever television fortune-tellers forecast Larry King’s eventual replacement, Katie Couric’s name was the first to be mentioned: one of the best interviewing jobs on television, and one of the best-known interviewers on television. It seemed a perfect match.

articles.headline: Hurdles Deter Obama’s Pledge to Double Exports
articles.snippet: Comments filed with the Commerce Department highlighted concerns, including the dollar’s rising value, high tariffs and traveling difficulties.
articles.abstract: Comments filed with the Commerce Department highlighted concerns, including the dollar’s rising value, high tariffs and traveling difficulties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When President Obama announced at his State of the Union address in January a goal of doubling American exports over five years, business owners applauded, envisioning a flood of goods moving into new markets in the Asian and Latin American countries that are leading the global recovery. The chief executives of Boeing and Xerox agreed to lead an advisory council to support the effort, called the National Export Initiative.

articles.headline: The Zeal of a Convert to Twitter
articles.snippet: After a savage televised rant against blogs two years ago, Buzz Bissinger today is a habitual Twitter user.
articles.abstract: After a savage televised rant against blogs two years ago, Buzz Bissinger today is a habitual Twitter user.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Buzz Bissinger took a stand against digital culture.

articles.headline: A Benchmark of Progress, Electrical Grid Fails Iraqis
articles.snippet: As the American combat mission officially ends this month, Iraq’s government is still struggling to provide one of the most basic services, generating disillusionment and dissent.
articles.abstract: As the American combat mission officially ends this month, Iraq’s government is still struggling to provide one of the most basic services, generating disillusionment and dissent.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Ikbal Ali, a bureaucrat in a beaded head scarf, accompanied by a phalanx of police officers, quickly found what she was out looking for in the summer swelter: electricity thieves. Six black cables stretched from a power pole to a row of auto-repair shops, siphoning what few hours of power Iraq’s straining system provides.

articles.headline: In House Ethics Battles, a Partywide Threat
articles.snippet: Charles B. Rangel and Maxine Waters face ethics trials that could cause a spectacle as Democrats fight to hold their majority.
articles.abstract: Charles B. Rangel and Maxine Waters face ethics trials that could cause a spectacle as Democrats fight to hold their majority.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  By defiantly pushing for full-fledged ethics trials, Representatives Charles B. Rangel and Maxine Waters are raising the prospect of a spectacle focusing on Congressional corruption this fall, just as Democrats are fighting to hold on to their majority in an election already defined by distrust of Washington.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: In Speech on Iraq, Obama Reaffirms Drawdown
articles.snippet: President Obama marked the end of the combat mission, “as promised and on schedule,” in a country still finding its way.
articles.abstract: President Obama marked the end of the combat mission, “as promised and on schedule,” in a country still finding its way.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA  President Obama on Monday opened a monthlong drive to mark the end of the combat mission in Iraq and, by extension, to blunt growing public frustration with the war in Afghanistan by arguing that he can also bring that conflict to a conclusion.
